A ring (admitting a unit element) is a set R together with two laws of composition written as addition '+' and multiplication '.' such that: (i) R is a commutative group with respect to addition. (ii) R is a monoid with respect to multiplication, i.e., the multiplication is associative, and there exists a unit element in R. (iii) The distributive laws hold, i.e., (a+b) 
cdot c=a 
cdot c+b 
cdot c, and c 
cdot(a+b)=c 
cdot a+c 
cdot b for all a, b, c in R.
System of Generators of an Ideal

Let $\mathfrak{a}$ be an ideal of a ring $R$. A family $\left(a_{i}\right)_{i \in I}$ of elements in $\mathfrak{a}$ is called a system of generators of $\mathfrak{a}$ if $\mathfrak{a}=\sum_{i \in I} R a_{i}$, i.e., if $\mathfrak{a}$ coincides with the ideal generated by the family $\left(a_{i}\right)_{i \in I}$.
Does the concept of a/an Ring need to be defined for a definition of a/an System of Generators of an Ideal to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The definition of a 'System of Generators of an Ideal' explicitly mentions that it pertains to an ideal of a ring $R$. An ideal is a subset of a ring that is closed under addition and under multiplication by any element of the ring. Therefore, the concept of an ideal inherently depends on the structure of a ring. Without the concept of a ring, the notion of an ideal cannot be defined, and consequently, a system of generators of an ideal, which relies on the existence and properties of an ideal, also cannot be defined. Thus, the concept of a ring is essential for the definition of a system of generators of an ideal to make sense.
